items.title: CasePack: Internal Communication & Ways of Working
items.text:
Subject: Welcome to Operations — quick intro & ways of working

Hi everyone,

Please join me in welcoming Alex Taylor to the Operations team. Alex will support day-to-day coordination across teams and help us keep requests moving.

Ways of working (recap):
1. Use the Ops Inbox for requests that can’t be solved within your team.
2. If a request is time-sensitive, flag it as Urgent and include a deadline.
3. We track work in the Ops Board (status: New / In progress / Blocked / Done).
4. If something is blocked for more than 24 hours, please escalate in the daily check-in.

Thanks,
Priya

vocabularyHelp.definition: Needing to be dealt with very quickly.
To involve higher management in a problem.

questions.question: What are the four statuses used on the Ops Board?
questions.explanation: The email specifies: New / In progress / Blocked / Done.

questions.question: When should an issue be escalated according to the email?
options: If it remains blocked for more than 24 hours
questions.explanation: The text states: 'If something is blocked for more than 24 hours, please escalate'.

questions.question: What two things must be done for time-sensitive requests?
options: Call Priya and send a Slack message
Use the Ops Board and the Ops Inbox
Flag as Urgent and include a deadline
questions.explanation: The email says: 'flag it as Urgent and include a deadline'.

items.prompt: According to the Escalation Guidelines, which of these is a valid reason to escalate?
options: A colleague has a difficult personality.
A customer-facing commitment is at risk.
You want to change the daily meeting time.
The Ops Inbox has too many emails.
items.explanation: Escalation is used when critical commitments are at risk.

items.prompt: Match the term with its correct definition in an Operations context.

pairs.definition: Person with an interest in the process
Specific task assigned in a meeting

items.prompt: Complete the phrase: 'Please ___ this as urgent and include a ___.'
items.explanation: In operations, we 'flag' items and include 'deadlines'.

items.prompt: Select the most neutral and professional way to describe a delay.
options: Your team is blocking us again, please fix it.
We can't do anything because Finance is slow.
We are experiencing a delay due to a pending approval from the Finance department.
The project is stuck because someone didn't sign the document.
items.explanation: Option 3 uses factual, non-blaming language ('experiencing a delay', 'pending approval').

items.prompt: Rephrase this to be more diplomatic: 'You didn't reply.'
options: I'm just following up on my previous email.
items.explanation: 'Following up' is the standard diplomatic way to inquire about a lack of response.

items.prompt: Draft a short introductory email (120-170 words) to your new team. Include your role, how to request help (Ops Inbox), how to flag urgent tasks, and an invitation to message you.
items.modelAnswer:
Subject: Hello from Ops — how to work with me

Hi everyone,

I’m Alex, and I’ve just joined Operations. I’ll be supporting day-to-day coordination across teams, helping to track requests, and keeping work moving when there are blockers or dependencies.

How to work with me:
- Send requests via the Ops inbox and include the desired outcome plus any relevant context.
- If something is time-sensitive, please flag it as Urgent and add a clear deadline.
- If you’re blocked by another team, tell me what you’ve tried so far and what you need (decision / confirmation / resource).

Happy to help — feel free to message me if you’re unsure where a request should go.

Thanks,
Alex

items.title: Daily Check-in Simulation
items.transcript: Speaker: Hi everyone. Yesterday I completed the internal audit of the onboarding files. Today, I'm focusing on setting up the new Ops Board for the Q3 project. I've hit a blocker with the permissions—I can't add external stakeholders yet. I'll escalate this to Priya if it's not resolved by this afternoon.

vocabularyHelp.definition: An official inspection of an organization's accounts or processes.
Official notice that allows you to do something (in software).
